Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation2: The carpenter should be on time in the work area
Story: I glanced at the clock on the wall of the workshop, my hands still dusty from sanding the oak beams. It was nearly noon, the time I always called my parents. Every week, without fail, I updated them on my life, listened to their stories, and made sure they were doing well. They looked forward to these calls, and so did I. But today, the foreman had just reminded us that a safety inspection was about to start, and everyone needed to be present and on time in the work area. Missing it could mean a warning or worse, and I knew how important it was to follow every protocol to keep the site safe. My phone buzzed in my pocket—a reminder for the call. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations: my parents waiting for my voice, the team counting on my presence. I felt torn, the pressure building inside me, knowing that whatever I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
